description: This used to be my neighborhood coffee shop and I absolutely love the coffee here. Sweet Italian blend is my favorite.  It's family owned and they are so friendly - it's a great way to start your day.  I still haven't found a place to top it.
author: Elizabeth P.

description: Best coffee actually on Castro if you avoid the flavored ones, ick. Much nicer than Rossi's across the street, both the coffee and the staff.
author: patrick g.

description: Walking around the Castro on a recent visit, I was passing by the Theater and smelled deliciousness emanating from the coffee shop next door.  I went in as I remembered a friend had recommended the place and was impressed immediately by the huge selection of whole bean coffee available.  Not only that, but the selection of fair trade and organic was one of the largest I've seen outside of Seattle.  I ordered a pound each of the Mexican Organic and the Moka Java and both tasted amazing.  At $8.50/lb for each of them, the price was great.  The place was staffed by a very friendly person who was great in explaining the difference between the dark and light roasts available for the Moka Java (dark being more flavorful but with less caffeine).  I didn't order coffee as that was the first day of my cold but someone in front of me was raving about their latte.  I tried to check-in on Yelp and was shocked they weren't on there so thought I'd add them.   Check this place out next time you're in San Francisco.
author: Tony R.

description: 5 Stars because your coffee rocks and you are an independent coffee shop...support your local merchant PEOPLE.  Quick, friendly service and a great "go to" place when you need to buy cheese for a party.  It's really about the coffee though.
author: Robert S.

description: Cheapest, most flavorful coffee in the Bay Area... with Peet's and Starburnt charging $12+ a pound, paying anywhere from $5 to $7 a pound is smart and delicious. My experience with the staff has always been sterling, even if they occasionally appear standoffish. Never gotten any cheese there,  but love the coffee.
author: Chris S.

description: Best deal on good quality coffee beans.  Well worth the trip to the Castro.  Friendly and helpful people too.
author: Iris J.

description: This place isnt a cheese place anymore, it's a coffee place. I think even the sign says castro coffee or something such as that. Anyway, ive always seen that they have breakfast sandwiches, right near the muni stop, very convenient, but I never went inside till yesterday, when I was on my way to a museum. J and I went in to grab a quick bite.. I got the spinach empanada with a small soy chai latte, and he got a breakfast sandwich on a croissant with a small mocha latte with soy. Wow. We could have gone to the grocery store and baked everything ourselves in shorter time. Mine was already made, all she had to do was microwave it. I thought she was done with that and ordered my tea, but didn't realize she was still on that, and hadn't even started the sandwich. By the time these four items were done, there was a giant line behind us. This woman moved in super slow motion. I felt really frustrated. I realize it doesn't have to be a fast food pace, but I would seriously have to TRY to move as slow as she did. She also was not responsive to things like hi, good morning... I felt like I fell into a slowness time warp, but didn't know if it was just me. After we left (in which time as I was paying, another employee popped in and rung up a guy's coffee bean order during the time it took her to ring up mine..she was that slow), I asked j and he was just as incredulous about the slowness as I was. As was our friend a, who was waiting for us outside. Those four items were $16. My food was ok, not bad, not good. My tea was not the best ever but pretty good. J thought his coffee was very good, the sandwich was kinda bleh with runny eggs. There is a huge variety of coffee beans there, so if I was a coffee person, maybe I'd come in for that. But if you're looking to grab breakfast in the morning, go someplace else. You'll miss your train, be super late for work, age 50 years, and only get a mediocre bleh meal for it. Maybe she was having a bad day, who knows. :)
author: Merredith L.

description: The best coffee in the castro, these boys know how to pull a shot. The cheese however is suspect, and is best avoided.
author: Stellah D.

description: If you love coffee you can't walk past this place and not step in for a cappuccino or a latte. The smell is irresistible and the coffee lives up to your expectations set by your nose. Although I had an excellent latte I was intrigued by their huge variety of coffee and cheese counter. This place is also very crowded and not for lingering.
author: R C.

description: Mmm for that coffee. Try the organic fair trade rocket espresso... it may convert the tea lovers to coffee fanatics in no time (it did me in!)
author: Anika K.

description: Fast and friendly.  Always a large selection of coffee, and many on special.  They also have a fair amount of teas, and associated paraphernalia.  I make it a point to come in here when I'm in the neighborhood to pick up my coffee supply.  It seems to me that while there are still some unique cheese offerings here, that the coffee portion of the store is dominant.
author: Ken B.

description: Tasty blended coffee available here.  Still wonder about the odd nomenclature though as their cheese selection paled in comparison to the bean choices.
author: Sam N.

description: Such good coffee. I didn't even think that they actually had cheese. It is super tiny so please do whatever you can to make more space, take off your backpack before you come in, or better yet don't walk in and just stand in the middle. These guys are really  good at what they do and it dosen't cost an outragous amount. It's my favorite coffee in the castro. If they ever have the pumpkin again, get it. I usually hate flavored coffees but this rocked my world.
author: Autumn R.

description: Tiny place. Great array of coffees and cheeses, fairly priced and even for coffee-on-the go, for the busy busy busy it's fantastic, my usual stop most mornings. Def a yes.
author: Adam B.

description: OMG what great coffee, what great proces. I am so in lust over that unwashed Costa Rican.
author: Razza M.

description: Great house coffee!!  I like this better than the burn't coffee at Starbucks!
author: Jay S.

description: Been doing business here for almost 30 years. A family business and one of the oldest and most trusted and respected businesses in the Castro. Wonderful to do business with. Love the decaf French roast the European Royal is THE best brew I've ever tried.
author: Jon W.

description: It's hard to find good, affordable bulk coffee. I don't much like the Trader Joe's options but I really like the selection of coffee at the Cheesery and usually try something new along with my very affordable staple, the Italian roast. I usually pick up some cheese and a biscotti, too. The owner is very nice, too.
author: Robert T.

description: Great place to get coffee.  I get my own special blend of coffee done and it only costs $10.50 for a pound and a HALF.  Take that Starbucks.
author: Rick R.

description: This is the nearest coffee shop to my new place. I walked by figuring I could stock up on some coffee and get some cheese for a small dinner party I was attending. I asked the counter person which organic dark coffee he recommended. There were signs all over for organic coffee at $6.50 a pound. He recommended one that looked to be $8.50/ pound. After he ground it for my espresso maker I asked to get some Brie. Nope, they only had Havarti and 2 other cheeses. What!? Only that. Fine. I'm ready just the coffee thank you. That will be $11.99. Excuse me!? The sign says $8.50. Counter guy came around the counter and showed me no, that in fact that $8.50 sign was for another blend who's name was hidden behind some kind of choco bar box. Well, what can I do now, it's already ground, I want to leave. So I hand over my card. No apology, no offer for a free cup of coffee. No nothing. I had expected to pay about $7/lb for coffee, left $12 poorer and without any cheese. While the coffee was delicious this morning, it wasn't blue bottle.
author: Leslie T.

description: The stench emanating from this place is so strong I can never get past the door.
author: Quartknee K.

description: How can you say anything bad about this place? It's tiny and cramped and usually there are lots of people in there - but don't be overwhelmed - the staff are so nice and patient, so take your time picking from the huge selection ask questions and browse the other goodies that are literally stacked to the ceiling. Despite the name, the thing to go for here is coffee. (The cheese is good too!) Cheap coffee, deluxe coffee, in-between coffee, standard coffee, custom blends, fair-trade coffee, organic coffee, and all combinations of such adjectives. I usually get a pound of fair-trade to ease my concience for the other pound of pure indulgence. My sister in-law lives in LA and orders by mail and it still works out reasonable. They have unusual imported cookies, snacks, pastries, espresso drinks, and hard to find coffee accessories (e.g. Chemex filters). Great place for gifts if you have a coffee fanatic in your life.
author: Kingpin X.
